1.12.text:
Alice: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Alice.

4.80.text: Alice: So Neil, did you sleep well last night?

6.72.text: Neil: Um, yes, thanks. Why do you ask?

9.20.text:
Alice: Today we're talking about how much
sleep we need.

12.16.text:
Neil: I like a good eight hours myself –
ten at the weekend. How about you?

17.15.text:
Alice: Six is enough for me. But did you know
this? Humans sleep around three hours less

23.28.text:
than other primates like chimps, who sleep
for about ten hours.

27.12.text: So you're a chimp, Neil... at the weekends, at least! Are you ready for the quiz question?

38.05.text:
Alice: OK, I'll assume that means yes. Right.
What's another word for sleepwalking? Is it...

46.45.text:
a) narcolepsy?
b) restless legs syndrome?

54.36.text:
Neil: I will go for b) restless legs syndrome,
since there's a connection there with the legs.

58.74.text:
Alice: Well we'll find out whether you're
right or wrong later on in the show.

62.80.text: So what keeps you awake at night, Neil?

65.23.text:
Neil: Not much, to be honest. I usually sleep
like a log

68.77.text: and that means very heavily indeed!

70.56.text:
But sometimes my own snoring wakes
me up, and then I can find it hard to get back to sleep.

75.72.text: Snoring, for those of you who don't know, means breathing in a noisy way

80.49.text:
through your mouth or nose while you're asleep.
[snores] ... like that... How about you, Alice?

87.00.text:
Alice: Very good, yes. Well, that's quite
ridiculous!

89.90.text: Anyway, for me, it's drinking too much coffee during the day.

94.34.text: It's the caffeine in coffee – a chemical that makes you feel more awake

98.88.text: which can stop you from sleeping at night.

101.30.text: But there are so many things that can keep us awake these days.

104.02.text:
Neil: Oh yes. Radio, TV... techy stuff like
24-hour internet, computers, smart phones.

110.08.text: I love my phone and it's never far from me!

112.14.text:
Alice: Well, let's hear what Professor Jerome
Siegel, from the University of California,

116.09.text:
found when he studied the sleep habits of
three different hunter-gatherer communities

120.56.text:
who have very little contact with modern society.
They don't have artificial light, electricity,

126.27.text:
batteries, or any of the gadgets that we rely
on today.

131.28.text:
Jerome Siegel: Their sleep was not that different
from ours.

133.90.text: The range of sleep period was about 6.9 to 8.5 hours.

140.58.text: If you actually measure sleep in current populations in the United States or in Europe

146.68.text: they're definitely at the low end of what's been reported.

150.06.text:
They certainly don't sleep a lot less than we do
but they clearly don't sleep more.

157.20.text:
Alice: Professor Jerome Siegel found that
people in these communities don't go to bed

161.58.text:
until several hours after sundown – just
like us!

165.14.text: But one big difference is that very few of them suffer from insomnia

169.22.text: which means having difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep.

172.68.text:
Neil: Now, I don't have a problem with insomnia.
And hunter-gatherers

176.58.text:
people who live by hunting animals and gathering plants to
eat – don't either

181.06.text: probably because they take a lot of physical exercise during the day.

185.86.text: Taking exercise is an important factor in sleeping soundly – or well – at night.

191.44.text: But these days our minds can be so active that it becomes very difficult to fall asleep.

196.52.text: Let's listen to Professor Kevin Morgan, from Loughborough University here in England,

201.06.text: talking about how cognitive behavioural therapy can be used to help people with insomnia.

207.52.text:
Kevin Morgan: If you have a train of thoughts
which would otherwise keep you awake one way

211.01.text: of dealing with this is to block those thoughts.

214.55.text: What I'd like you to do is repeat the word 'the' in your mind at irregular intervals

220.88.text: the the the the the the the the the

226.76.text:
what you'll find (is) that the mind space
required to do this blocks out almost everything else.

234.10.text:
Neil: So Professor Kevin Morgan suggests saying
one word over and over again at irregular intervals

240.04.text: irregular in this context means not spaced out evenly.

244.04.text: Doing it can help to block out the thoughts that are stopping you from getting to sleep.

248.78.text: It sounds like a very simple solution. I wonder if it works?

252.26.text:
Alice: There's one way to find out, Neil.
Try it yourself!

255.95.text:
Alice: OK. And cognitive behavioural therapy
by the way is a treatment for mental health

260.49.text:
problems that tries to change the way you
think.

263.36.text:
Neil: Well, I usually count sheep if I can't
get to sleep. Do you do that, Alice?

267.36.text:
Alice: No, not usually. No. OK, I think it's
time for the answer to our quiz question.

273.34.text:
I asked: What's another word for sleepwalking?
Is it... a) narcolepsy? b) restless legs syndrome?

284.64.text: Neil: And I said b) restless legs syndrome.

287.76.text:
Alice: Sorry, Neil, it's actually c) somnambulism
– the roots of this word come from Latin.

294.48.text:
Somnus means 'sleep' and and ambulare means
'walk'.

298.68.text: Narcolepsy is a condition where you can't stop yourself falling asleep, especially during the day.

304.90.text: Neil: Narcolepsy... (says in a sleepy way)

307.45.text:
Alice: And restless legs syndrome is a condition
that makes you desperate to move your legs around,

312.50.text: especially when you're sitting quietly or trying to get to sleep.

326.31.text:
Alice: Hello! Can we hear today's words again,
please?

350.02.text:
Alice: Well, that just about brings us to
the end of this edition of 6 Minute English.

354.58.text: We hope you've enjoyed this programme.

356.46.text: Please do join us again soon.
